facts.text: Two appellants, Kunjilal and Deopal (father and son, latter aged 17), prosecuted under section 392 and section 332, Indian Penal Code, in Court of Magistrate, Sagar.
Sentenced under s.392 to 1 year rigorous imprisonment and under s.332 to fine of Rs.500 each.
On appeal, convictions upheld; Kunjilal's sentence reduced to six months R.I. and Rs.350 fine; Deopal bound over under s.562 CrPC, imprisonment set aside, fine under s.332 reduced to Rs.250.
Revision to High Court of Judicature at Nagpur dismissed on 12th November 1952.
Export of rice and ghee prohibited from Madhya Pradesh under s.7 Essential Supplies (Temporary Powers) Act, 1946.
Three bullock carts belonging to appellants carrying bags of rice and tins of ghee crossing river Dhasan on MP-UP border on 1st March 1949.
Head Constable Abdul Samad, on information, reached spot, seized prohibited goods in mid-stream, allowed cart-men to take carts to other side for meals, then brought back to Shahgarh in MP.
In jungle near Shahgarh, appellants allegedly beat Head Constable and took away seized property to house of Paltu Bania at Bagrohi.
Appellants denied offence; pleaded goods going to Baraitha in MP, not UP, and did not beat Head Constable.
Magistrate found offences proved, accepted prosecution evidence on beating and exporting contraband; medical evidence supported.
Additional Sessions Judge found story of going to Baraitha false as route to Baraitha does not pass through Dhasan river; carts caught at other bank but seizure legal as in mid-stream.
Appellants prosecuted under s.7 Essential Supplies Act; convicted by Magistrate but acquitted on appeal by Additional Sessions Judge on 31 October 1952.

legal_issues.text: Whether there was absence of mens rea necessary under section 392 IPC, as appellants honestly believed they were taking goods to a place within Madhya Pradesh.
Whether appellants could be tried under ss.332 and 392 IPC after acquittal under s.7 Essential Supplies Act, in view of s.403 CrPC (double jeopardy).

petitioner_arguments.text: Absence of mens rea under s.392; honestly believed taking goods to Baraitha in MP when caught in mid-stream.
Already prosecuted and acquitted under s.7 Essential Supplies Act; s.403(1) CrPC bars trial for same offence or on same facts for different charge under ss.236/237 CrPC.
Seizure illegal as took place beyond MP border.

court_reasoning.text: In special leave appeal under Art.136, not open to re-agitate questions of fact; findings of courts below binding.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Findings of fact must be accepted as binding.

court_reasoning.text: Mens rea contention negatived by finding that route chosen did not lead to Baraitha or any place in MP but to UP.
Ss.236/237 CrPC do not apply; s.403(2) CrPC allows trial for distinct offence for which separate charge might have been made under s.235(1).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ss.332/392 IPC are distinct offences from s.7 Essential Supplies Act.

court_reasoning.text: To sustain charges under ss.332/392, court considers if seizure legal by public servant in discharge of duty; findings concurrent that appellants committed robbery and hurt.
Carts captured before crossing UP border (mid-stream); seizure legal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Evidence accepted that seizure in mid-stream.

holdings.text: No absence of mens rea under s.392 IPC.
s.403(2) CrPC permits trial for distinct offences under ss.332/392 IPC after acquittal under s.7 Essential Supplies Act.
Seizure legal as carts seized in mid-stream before crossing UP border.

outcome.summary: Appeal under Art.136 dismissed; convictions under ss.332/392 IPC and reduced sentences upheld; no substance in contentions on mens rea or double jeopardy.

key_quotes.text: "In a Special Leave to Appeal under article 136, it is not open to the appellants to re-agitate questions of fact and ask the Court to disturb the findings of fact arrived at by the Courts below."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits scope of appeal to legal issues only.

key_quotes.text: "Sub-section (2) of section 403 in our opinion furnishes a complete answer to the contention raised on behalf of the appellants."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "We hold that there is no substance in this contention."
